newsitem.title: FRANCE: Danone reports higher first-half profit.
newsitem.headline: Danone reports higher first-half profit.

text.p: Food giant Danone on Wednesday reported that first-half profit rose as a surge in its business outside Europe helped offset a rise in French taxes.

The company, best known for its yoghurts but also a seller of mineral waters, biscuits, pasta and beer, said its net attributable profit increased 2.3 percent to 1.73 billion francs ($340.3 million) from 1.70 billion in the first half of 1995.
Operating profit rose 4.3 percent to 3.70 billion francs, while sales climbed 4.1 percent to 41.59 billion.

The comparison between Danone's first-half net income and the prior-year result is skewed by a rise in French taxes last year which applied to the full year but were recorded only in the second half, the company said.
"After adjustment for this factor, net income for the first half of 1996 showed a 5.1 percent increase," it said in a statement.
Danone confirmed its previous forecast for a six percent full year profit rise.

"Operating income from business outside western Europe rose 26.4 percent to make a significantly larger contribution to the consolidated total," said Danone, whose foreign activities range from biscuit factories in China to dairy firms in Argentina.

Within Europe, operating income rose in Danone's dairy products, biscuits, mineral water and containers activities in the first half but declined in grocery products, pasta and beer. ($ = 5.084 French Francs)
